reviewText: This is by far the quintessential PPM concert. Even though this was recorded 26 years ago; it is still just as fresh and relevant as it was in 1986, because sadly we still struggle with so many issues addressed in their music. But it isn't all what some prefer to call "Protest Songs" there are light-hearted moments to make you laugh; and in light of Mary's passing a few tears for her presence no longer with us. I would highly recommend this concert dvd to all PPM fans; and those who have yet to discover the truth and beauty of their music.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When Peter, Paul & Mary came to Nashville to record their 25th Anniversary Concert for PBS in 1986, I was fortunate to attend. Recorded in Nashville's Tennessee Performing Arts Center in Jackson Hall, the concert was taped on two consecutive nights. We were there on the second night and there was a bit of concern when Mary's beautiful necklace broke, fearing the footage wouldn't match the previous night's recording. Sure enough, you can see that Mary's necklace is missing toward the end of the concert. A fan for many years, I was not disappointed. I am still amazed to hear how full their sound is with nothing more than two guitars, Dick Kniss on the upright bass and those three glorious voices. It was a sweet, unforgettable show and this DVD somehow managed to capture the feel in the room. The music is so infectious that the audience sings along whether prompted or not. I count myself blessed to have heard them in their prime before we lost dear Mary Travers. Any fan of PP&M will cherish this DVD.
summary: An eyewitness to this concert ... LIVE!

reviewText: I enjoy music. My wife and I have season tickets to classical concerts. Frequently we go even though we are tired from working, but by the time we leave we feel energized. But we also enjoy folk music and miss it. We enjoy the sound and the messages. Thus we found this Peter Paul and Mary concert, which we had seen about two decades ago, really enjoyable, and also energizing. It was a pleasure to hear again the songs we heard during a different time in the US. Although written to speak to our nation about the problems of the time, the music is still pleasurable, and when we think about it, the messages are still relevant.
summary: Although 25 years old, the music is still very enjoyable
Title: N/A

reviewText: Over the years I have seen on TV several concerts of various performers and have collected on DVD abd VHS as well. Of all the concerts I have watched on TV or DVD "Peter Paul and Mary's 25th Anniversary Concert just might be the best of the best I have seen. I write that not because I am a hugh fam of PP&M; (althought it is true I am) but because the atmosphere that was going on inside the Tennessee Performing Arts Center that night the concert was being recorded. Peter Paul And Mary have been a major contributor to the world of music since the early 1960's when folk music was at its height in popularity. Their songs, especially the lyrics, brought attention to the political issues that was facing society and helped inspire society to meet those issues head on correct the problems that were hindering progress. Folk music doesn't hold the attention of the majority of the public nowadays as it did back fourty or fifty years ago but it doesn't make the songs any less important or inspiring. Sadly too some of those issues that folk music was addressing way back then are still with us today and still hindering the progress of society to become greater.But one night 25 years ago all the hopes and enthusiasm that folk music could bring out in people occurred with the trio of Peter Paul and Mary leading once again the way. During the concert PP&M; would sing all of the songs we have come to associate with them. They touched all emotions as they weaved through their line up of songs they played. There was a little something for everyone. Songs of humour, hope, protest, remembrence and all with some nostalgia thrown in as well. Just about all of the songs on the concert you know. The concert is also a perfect blend of newer songs they wrote combined together with their well known and loved hits. It all combines together to create a true concert event. What to me makes this so enjoyable to watch is to see the reaction to the audience as the concert goes on. Everyone in the audience seemed to get right into the spirit of the concert right from the beginning. The camera shots that are shown throughtout the performance shows everyone really getting into the music and the emotions coming from the music. Just about every song the audience is singing along too and in a couple of cases PP and M stop singing themselves and let the audience take over singing the lyrics. It seemed that as it progressed along both Peter Paul and Mary and the audience were feeding off each others emotions that were coming forth which just helped bring an electricity into the air that made the whole evening become so special. I remember the first time I watched it,on our local PBS station, I thought how much I wish I had been there to be a part of what was taking place.I did get the concert on VHS after seeing it on TV but that was many years ago and the tape is wearing out now. The good news though is that in memory to that 25th anniversary concert 25 years later it is being released on DVD. I of course will plan on getting me a copy and I strongly recommend you getting yourself a copy to. Especially if your are a fan of PP&M;, this is a must to have. I would also recommend this to anyone who is not familier with the music of Peter Paul and Mary. This concert I think makes an excellant introdution to the spirit and love as well as the music of this greatest of folk music trios.

They give knew meaning to the songs as they bring the audiance into being their co-performers and the songs will never be the same to me again. reviewText: Just the opposite of Simon and Garfunkel, these three seem like they are at their best in front of an audience.  I just love watching them while they sing.  The expressions on their faces and the joy they seem to experience just really pull the viewer in - even my kids who think P P and M are for old people join me when I put their concerts on.  Great family fun!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I initially saw this back in 1986 when it first appeared on PBS and taped it on the VHS when I got the chance.  I was glad when this came out so I could get a version on DVD.  It is undoubtedly the best of the many PP&M concerts that came out on PBS during the band's later years.  They obviously enjoyed performing in front of a live audience and this is apparent during this broadcast.  Even given how dated some of the protest songs are in this day and age, they are still timeless in their appeal and in this performance.  I really enjoyed this show and would recommend it unreservedly to anyone who enjoys good music and fine singing.
summary: The best of the PP&M PBS concerts
Title: N/A

reviewText: I always enjoyed listening to the trio's folk-songs, including the now traditional American Civil rights songs and the anti-war songs.  There really doesn't seem to be enough videos of this group, (I could only find one other DVD), so I jumped at the chance to get this DVD.Four songs have always stood out for me and they are "Where Have All The Flowers Gone," "Blowin In The Wind," "Leaving On A Jet Plane," and "If I Had A Hammer".  There is one more song that I absolutely love and it is actually Paul's solo song, called "Wedding Song (There is Love)".  This highly spiritual song was presented as a special and unique wedding gift from Paul to Peter and his bride at their wedding.  All these songs are in this DVD and I found them enjoyable to watch.The concert was recorded in 1986, so the DVD quality looks slightly dated and a little fuzzy (grainy) on a 1080 high def TV.  If you have older DVDs you probably know what I mean.  On a 720 high def TV, closeups look OK and the background audience was a littly fuzzy.Audio sounds fine on the regular speakers of the 1080 high def TV.  Audio sounds great on an audio system.  (Didn't they always sound great on their CDs?).I hope more videos of this group will be issued.  As Mary has passed away, there will be no more new songs as a trio from these great artists of their time.Mary's name always appeared last, but in my Book, her name always appeared first.

reviewText: I was eagerly looking forward to receiving this concert after seeing it on PBS.  Playing it for the first time my expectations dropped.  While the concert and performers were excellent, the quality of the video was very dated, and not the quality I had experienced when viewing it on PBS.  If you can overlook the video quality then you will enjoy the concert.  I don't mean that the viewing is extremely bad, it's just that you should expect video quality dating back to the 80's, as this has not been restored to higer quality as other TV shows have been.  Would I purchase this if I had known about the quality, most likely I would have passed on purchasing this DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When I heard about this, I got pretty excited about it because it was advertized as the 1st PBS concert recording of Peter, Paul and Mary. Well, it's not.Because the actual 1st PBS Peter, Paul and Mary special is much older than this.  It may have been in the mid-1970's (after the breakup). They were MUCH younger and much STRONGER performers then.  They opened the show with a stirring rendition of "The Times They Are a Changing" and Mary looked stunning in a tight sparkling blue dress.  She was slender and really hot back then and her earnest singing on that song was a real turn on (on several levels!).At any rate, I wish THAT broadcast was being released...I taped it on Beta but lost the tape (and the BetaMax) years ago.  For all I know, it was live and never saved on video tape by PBS.  A darn shame.This show is good but not great.  I owned it on VHS and traded it in to Record Traders because I wasn't too happy with the show.  It suffered in comparision from the earlier broadcast that has evidently been lost to time.
Title: N/A
